33 This is a byte oriented version of SHA1 that operates on arrays of bytes

37#include <string.h> /* for memcpy() etc. */
38#include <stdlib.h> /* for _lrotl with VC++ */
39
40#if defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNU_LIBRARY__)
41//#include <byteswap.h>
42//#include <endian.h>
43#endif
44
45#include "sha1.h"
46
47#if defined(__cplusplus)
48extern "C"
49{
50#endif
51
52/*
53 To obtain the highest speed on processors with 32-bit words, this code
54 needs to determine the order in which bytes are packed into such words.
55 The following block of code is an attempt to capture the most obvious
56 ways in which various environemnts specify their endian definitions.
57 It may well fail, in which case the definitions will need to be set by
58 editing at the points marked **** EDIT HERE IF NECESSARY **** below.
59*/
60#define SHA_LITTLE_ENDIAN 1234 /* byte 0 is least significant (i386) */
61#define SHA_BIG_ENDIAN 4321 /* byte 0 is most significant (mc68k) */
62
63#if !defined(PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER)
64#if defined(LITTLE_ENDIAN) || defined(BIG_ENDIAN)
65# if defined(LITTLE_ENDIAN) && defined(BIG_ENDIAN)
66# if defined(BYTE_ORDER)
67# if (BYTE_ORDER == LITTLE_ENDIAN)
68# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_LITTLE_ENDIAN
69# elif (BYTE_ORDER == BIG_ENDIAN)
70# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_BIG_ENDIAN
71# endif
72# endif
73# elif defined(LITTLE_ENDIAN) && !defined(BIG_ENDIAN)
74# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_LITTLE_ENDIAN
75# elif !defined(LITTLE_ENDIAN) && defined(BIG_ENDIAN)
76# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_BIG_ENDIAN
77# endif
78#elif defined(_LITTLE_ENDIAN) || defined(_BIG_ENDIAN)
79# if defined(_LITTLE_ENDIAN) && defined(_BIG_ENDIAN)
80# if defined(_BYTE_ORDER)
81# if (_BYTE_ORDER == _LITTLE_ENDIAN)
82# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_LITTLE_ENDIAN
83# elif (_BYTE_ORDER == _BIG_ENDIAN)
84# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_BIG_ENDIAN
85# endif
86# endif
87# elif defined(_LITTLE_ENDIAN) && !defined(_BIG_ENDIAN)
88# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_LITTLE_ENDIAN
89# elif !defined(_LITTLE_ENDIAN) && defined(_BIG_ENDIAN)
90# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_BIG_ENDIAN
91# endif
92#elif 0 /* **** EDIT HERE IF NECESSARY **** */
93#define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_LITTLE_ENDIAN
94#elif 0 /* **** EDIT HERE IF NECESSARY **** */
95#define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_BIG_ENDIAN
96#elif (('1234' >> 24) == '1')
97# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_LITTLE_ENDIAN
98#elif (('4321' >> 24) == '1')
99# define PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER SHA_BIG_ENDIAN
100#endif
101#endif
102
103#if !defined(PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER)
104# error Please set undetermined byte order (lines 87 or 89 of sha1.c).
105#endif
106
107#define rotl32(x,n) (((x) << n) | ((x) >> (32 - n)))
108
109#if (PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER == SHA_BIG_ENDIAN)
110#define swap_b32(x) (x)
111#elif defined(bswap_32)
112#define swap_b32(x) bswap_32(x)
113#else
114#define swap_b32(x) ((rotl32((x), 8) & 0x00ff00ff) | (rotl32((x), 24) & 0xff00ff00))
115#endif
116
117#define SHA1_MASK (SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE - 1)
118
119/* reverse byte order in 32-bit words */
120
121#define ch(x,y,z) (((x) & (y)) ^ (~(x) & (z)))
122#define parity(x,y,z) ((x) ^ (y) ^ (z))
123#define maj(x,y,z) (((x) & (y)) ^ ((x) & (z)) ^ ((y) & (z)))
124
125/* A normal version as set out in the FIPS */
126
127#define rnd(f,k) \
128 t = a; a = rotl32(a,5) + f(b,c,d) + e + k + w[i]; \
129 e = d; d = c; c = rotl32(b, 30); b = t
130
131void sha1_compile(sha1_ctx ctx[1])
132{ sha1_32t w[80], i, a, b, c, d, e, t;
133
134 /* note that words are compiled from the buffer into 32-bit */
135 /* words in big-endian order so an order reversal is needed */
136 /* here on little endian machines */
137 for(i = 0; i < SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE / 4; ++i)
138 w[i] = swap_b32(ctx->wbuf[i]);
139
140 for(i = SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE / 4; i < 80; ++i)
141 w[i] = rotl32(w[i - 3] ^ w[i - 8] ^ w[i - 14] ^ w[i - 16], 1);
142
143 a = ctx->hash[0];
144 b = ctx->hash[1];
145 c = ctx->hash[2];
146 d = ctx->hash[3];
147 e = ctx->hash[4];
148
149 for(i = 0; i < 20; ++i)
150 {
151 rnd(ch, 0x5a827999);
152 }
153
154 for(i = 20; i < 40; ++i)
155 {
156 rnd(parity, 0x6ed9eba1);
157 }
158
159 for(i = 40; i < 60; ++i)
160 {
161 rnd(maj, 0x8f1bbcdc);
162 }
163
164 for(i = 60; i < 80; ++i)
165 {
166 rnd(parity, 0xca62c1d6);
167 }
168
169 ctx->hash[0] += a;
170 ctx->hash[1] += b;
171 ctx->hash[2] += c;
172 ctx->hash[3] += d;
173 ctx->hash[4] += e;
174}
175
176void sha1_begin(sha1_ctx ctx[1])
177{
178 ctx->count[0] = ctx->count[1] = 0;
179 ctx->hash[0] = 0x67452301;
180 ctx->hash[1] = 0xefcdab89;
181 ctx->hash[2] = 0x98badcfe;
182 ctx->hash[3] = 0x10325476;
183 ctx->hash[4] = 0xc3d2e1f0;
184}
185
186/* SHA1 hash data in an array of bytes into hash buffer and */
187/* call the hash_compile function as required. */
188
189void sha1_hash(const unsigned char data[], unsigned int len, sha1_ctx ctx[1])
190{ sha1_32t pos = (sha1_32t)(ctx->count[0] & SHA1_MASK),
191 space = SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE - pos;
192 const unsigned char *sp = data;
193
194 if((ctx->count[0] += len) < len)
195 ++(ctx->count[1]);
196
197 while(len >= space) /* tranfer whole blocks if possible */
198 {
199 memcpy(((unsigned char*)ctx->wbuf) + pos, sp, space);
200 sp += space; len -= space; space = SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE; pos = 0;
201 sha1_compile(ctx);
202 }
203
204 /*lint -e{803} conceivable data overrun */
205 /* there are two cases: the above while loop entered or not */
206 /* entered. If not entered, 'space = SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE - pos' */
207 /* and 'len < space' so that 'len + pos < SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE'. */
208 /* If entered, 'pos = 0', 'space = SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE' and */
209 /* 'len < space' so that 'pos + len < SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE'. In */
210 /* both cases, therefore, the memory copy is in the buffer */
211
212 memcpy(((unsigned char*)ctx->wbuf) + pos, sp, len);
213}
214
215/* SHA1 final padding and digest calculation */
216
217#if (PLATFORM_BYTE_ORDER == SHA_LITTLE_ENDIAN)
218static sha1_32t mask[4] =
219 { 0x00000000, 0x000000ff, 0x0000ffff, 0x00ffffff };
220static sha1_32t bits[4] =
221 { 0x00000080, 0x00008000, 0x00800000, 0x80000000 };
222#else
223static sha1_32t mask[4] =
224 { 0x00000000, 0xff000000, 0xffff0000, 0xffffff00 };
225static sha1_32t bits[4] =
226 { 0x80000000, 0x00800000, 0x00008000, 0x00000080 };
227#endif
228
229void sha1_end(unsigned char hval[], sha1_ctx ctx[1])
230{ sha1_32t i = (sha1_32t)(ctx->count[0] & SHA1_MASK);
231
232 /* mask out the rest of any partial 32-bit word and then set */
233 /* the next byte to 0x80. On big-endian machines any bytes in */
234 /* the buffer will be at the top end of 32 bit words, on little */
235 /* endian machines they will be at the bottom. Hence the AND */
236 /* and OR masks above are reversed for little endian systems */
237 /* Note that we can always add the first padding byte at this */
238 /* point because the buffer always has at least one empty slot */
239 ctx->wbuf[i >> 2] = (ctx->wbuf[i >> 2] & mask[i & 3]) | bits[i & 3];
240
241 /* we need 9 or more empty positions, one for the padding byte */
242 /* (above) and eight for the length count. If there is not */
243 /* enough space pad and empty the buffer */
244 if(i > SHA1_BLOCK_SIZE - 9)
245 {
246 if(i < 60) ctx->wbuf[15] = 0;
247 sha1_compile(ctx);
248 i = 0;
249 }
250 else /* compute a word index for the empty buffer positions */
251 i = (i >> 2) + 1;
252
253 while(i < 14) /* and zero pad all but last two positions */
254 ctx->wbuf[i++] = 0;
255
256 /* assemble the eight byte counter in in big-endian format */
257 ctx->wbuf[14] = swap_b32((ctx->count[1] << 3) | (ctx->count[0] >> 29));
258 ctx->wbuf[15] = swap_b32(ctx->count[0] << 3);
259
260 sha1_compile(ctx);
261
262 /* extract the hash value as bytes in case the hash buffer is */
263 /* misaligned for 32-bit words */
264 /*lint -e{504} unusual shift operation (unusually formed right argument) */
265 for(i = 0; i < SHA1_DIGEST_SIZE; ++i)
266 hval[i] = (unsigned char)(ctx->hash[i >> 2] >> (8 * (~i & 3)));
267}
268
269void sha1(unsigned char hval[], const unsigned char data[], unsigned int len)
270{ sha1_ctx cx[1];
271
272 sha1_begin(cx); sha1_hash(data, len, cx); sha1_end(hval, cx);
273}
274
275#if defined(__cplusplus)
276}
277#endif
